question: What is version control?
correctAnswer: The practice of tracking and managing changes to software code
incorrectAnswers: Only updating OS/languages to non-beta versions
Ensuring dependencies of the same library share the same version
Remembering to update your SDK

question: What is a branch in git?
correctAnswer: An independent line of development
incorrectAnswers: A node of a binary tree
The entirety of the project
A piece of code being reviewed

question: What is a merge conflict?
correctAnswer: Local changes compete with code on the same line(s)
incorrectAnswers: When your PR is blocked by another developer
Cached data not matching new code changes
Writing code in an unexpected language

question: What is CI (continuous integration)?
correctAnswer: The practice of automating the integration of code changes into a single project
incorrectAnswers: The practice of automatically deploying code changes to a testing/production environment
The practice of every change that passes the production pipeline is released to customers
The practice of manually integrating the code changes into a single project

question: What is CD (continuous delivery)?
correctAnswer: The practice of automatically deploying code changes to a testing/production environment
incorrectAnswers: The practice of automating the integration of code changes into a single project
The practice of every change that passes the production pipeline is released to customers
The practice of manually deploying code changes to a testing/production environment

question: What is git merge?
correctAnswer: Taking the independent lines of development and integrate them into a single branch
incorrectAnswers: The process of moving/combining a sequence of commits to a new base commit
Matching your cached data with your data source
The practice of merging your every active branch simultaneously

question: What is git rebase?
correctAnswer: The process of moving/combining a sequence of commits to a new base commit
incorrectAnswers: Taking the independent lines of development and integrate them into a single branch
Refreshing cached data to a previous state
Returning to the latest version of the repository

question: How do merge and rebase differ?
correctAnswer: Merging preserves the history of the branches, rebasing rewrites it
incorrectAnswers: Rebasing preserves the history of the branches, merging rewrites it
Merge can be done locally while, rebase can only be done in GitHub
Both are the same, the difference is based on programming language used

question: What is git stash?
correctAnswer: Temporarily store your changes you have made to your working copy, usually to be applied later
incorrectAnswers: Store you working changes to a text file for you to reference later
Stores your working changes to your commit without needing a message
Used to store changes to specific storage, like a file or USB drive

question: What is git status?
correctAnswer: Displays the state of the working directory and the staging area
incorrectAnswers: Displays and compared the commits and branches from your local branch and another branch
Displays if the branch is safe to push
Displays current errors and potential lint issues

question: What is a PR (pull request)?
correctAnswer: Lets other know about the changes you have pushed from your branch into the development branch
incorrectAnswers: The request to pull code from the repository to your device. Needs credentials
The process of moving/combining a sequence of commits to a new base commit
The practice of managing and disseminating information from an individual or an organization

question: What is CD (continuous deployment)?
correctAnswer: The practice of every change that passes the production pipeline is released to customers
incorrectAnswers: The practice of automating the integration of code changes into a single project
The practice of automatically deploying code changes to a testing/production environment
The practice of cherry picking your branch to merge it into production

question: What does the command git config do?
correctAnswer: Used to set Git configuration values on a global or local project level
incorrectAnswers: Used to view the Git configuration values on a global or local project level
Used to configure which files will be ignored upon pushing the branch
Used to configure which language Git should expect in this repository

question: What does HEAD represent in git?
correctAnswer: The current commit you are viewing
incorrectAnswers: The master branch
The branch you branched off of
The one who created the repository

question: What is the command pattern you follow to push your code?
correctAnswer: [git add .]-> [git commit -m "commit message"] -> [git push]
incorrectAnswers: [git push], Android Studio is aware of my local changes and pushes only those
[git add .]-> [git commit] -> [git push]
[git push --set-upstream origin <branch_name>]

question: What is git pull?
correctAnswer: Fetches the content from the remote repository and updates local repository to match it
incorrectAnswers: The command needed to start a pull request
Downloads commits, files, and refs from the remote repository into your local repository
Pulls the code from previous commit under your profile

question: What is git fetch?
correctAnswer: Downloads commits, files, and refs from the remote repository into your local repository
incorrectAnswers: Fetches the content from the remote repository and updates local repository to match it
The command needed to start a push request
Fetches the credentials of your GitHub account

question: What is git diff?
correctAnswer: Used to compare two commits, branches, or files across revisions or branches
incorrectAnswers: Displays the state of the working directory and the staging area
Pulls the code from previous commit under your profile
Displays your cached data with your data source

question: Which is not a benefit of version control?
correctAnswer: Easy duplication of code
incorrectAnswers: Traceability
Compliance adherence
Documentation history

question: What is meant by the repository in git?
correctAnswer: The entirety of the project
incorrectAnswers: The development branch
The code you are working on
The GitHub website

question: What is the least important thing you should look for in a PR?
correctAnswer: Does the code run
incorrectAnswers: Is the code following best practices
Does it solve the problem in the ticket
Is the solution code being covered by tests
